an3.123:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusināra, in the Forest of Offerings.
an3.123:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
an3.123:2.1: “Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
an3.123:2.2: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.
an3.123:2.3: The mendicant accepts if they want.
an3.123:2.4: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.
an3.123:2.5: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
an3.123:3.2: ‘It’s so good that this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods.’
an3.123:3.4: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods in the future, too.’
an3.123:3.5: They eat that food tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.
an3.123:3.6: They think about it with sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.
an3.123:3.7: A gift to such a mendicant is not very fruitful, I say.
an3.123:4.1: Take another case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
an3.123:4.2: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.
an3.123:4.3: The mendicant accepts if they want.
an3.123:4.4: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.
an3.123:4.5: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
an3.123:5.2: ‘It’s so good that the householder or their child serves and satisfies me with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.’
an3.123:5.4: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods in the future, too.’
an3.123:5.5: They eat that alms-food untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
an3.123:5.6: They think about it with thoughts of renunciation, good will, or harmlessness.
an3.123:5.7: A gift to such a mendicant is very fruitful, I say.
